key_points: Former President Donald Trump falsely claimed that his supporters were 'hugging and kissing' police during the January 6 Capitol riot.
Trump's comments are an attempt to rewrite the history of the insurrection, despite evidence of violence and five deaths.
He criticized the beefed-up security at the US Capitol as 'disgraceful' and a 'political maneuver.'
Trump suggested some rioters should face repercussions but quickly attacked Antifa, drawing a false equivalency.
Fox News' Laura Ingraham asked Trump if people who commit crimes should be prosecuted, to which he agreed.
The mob aimed to stop Congress from certifying President Joe Biden's win in the 2020 election.
Over 100 police officers were injured and five people died as a result of the riot.
Trump's 'hugging and kissing' remark may refer to limited interactions but ignores overall violence.
Criminal complaints against riot participants show the severity of the threats against lawmakers.
Trump has been accused in lawsuits by Democratic lawmakers of stoking the riot but denies responsibility.
